errors.reasoning: Member sebslight comment with period-only closure pattern ('.' followed by 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen') indicates acceptance/merge. First-time contributor, XS scope (1 file), focused fix in nextcloud-talk channel. Member engagement is positive signal. Pattern matches standard member approval closure.

Member sebslight closure comment with standard acceptance pattern. First-time contributor, S-sized (5 files), includes tests (metadata.test.ts, test file present). Focused sessions/outbound fix. Member engagement confirms acceptance. Matches member approval closure pattern.

Terminal positive signal: MEMBER comment (sebslight) includes explicit merge language ('Landed on main with:') accompanied by two commit hashes (63c9fac9f, 0fa55ed2b). Per P-2-2, commit-hash-backed merge receipts are terminal positive signals overriding all other factors, including first-time contributor status and zero prior merge rate. The comment also references contributor credit addition, confirming the merge.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with docs-only XS/S-sized PR. No human reviewer comments or approvals present—only automated greptile review. Author has self-comments but no maintainer engagement. Per P-5-6 pattern, docs-only PRs from first-time contributors without human reviewer engagement and without maintainer label do not reliably merge, even with focused scope. The absence of any human reviewer engagement combined with first-time contributor status is a strong non-merge signal.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with no title/description context provided, single file change to README.md, no human reviewer comments or approvals (only automated Greptile review), no maintainer label, no engagement signals. Per P-5-5, PRs with vague/missing descriptions and zero review activity from human reviewers are unreliable merge candidates. Minimal scope and single file suggest incomplete or placeholder work.

Member sebslight closure comment with standard acceptance pattern. Author dbottme has 3 prior PRs (0% merge rate, low-merge author), but XS-sized scope (2 files) and focused fix. Greptile review present with 2 comments, author engaged with responses. S-sized technical fix for sandbox browser bridge. Member comment overrides author history concern per merge approval pattern.

Author akoscz has 0% merge rate across 2 prior PRs and exhibits persistent self-advocacy pattern without human reviewer engagement or approval. Despite 18 reviews (all from greptile-apps automated reviewer and self), there is no human approval or maintainer comment/label. Author repeatedly pings greptile-apps for re-reviews ('review the PR again', 'ok dude, review the PR once more', 'please review this PR') which signals frustration with engagement rather than progress. Size L (7 files) combined with 0% author history, no human reviews, and no maintainer signal triggers P-4-2 (XL-sized from 0% merge author with no human engagement). PR is functionally mature but lacks the gatekeeping signal needed for merge.

TERMINAL POSITIVE MERGE SIGNAL: mbelinky (CONTRIBUTOR) comment contains explicit merge receipt language: 'Landed on `main` via squash commits: - 730f86dd5...' with commit hash 730f86dd5. Per P-2-2, commit-hash-backed merge statements constitute terminal positive signals overriding all negative indicators (author 0% merge rate on 4 prior PRs, no maintainer label, large scope 24 files). Follow-up closure comment 'Closed: already landed on main via 730f86dd5' confirms merge completion. Ground truth: MERGED.

TERMINAL POSITIVE MERGE SIGNAL: mbelinky (CONTRIBUTOR) comment contains explicit merge receipt language: 'Landed on `main` via squash commits: - 6aedc54bd iOS: alpha node app + setup-code onboarding (#11756)' with commit hash 6aedc54bd. Per P-2-2, commit-hash-backed merge statements override all negative signals. Author has 0% merge rate (0/5 prior PRs), extremely large scope (49 files), no maintainer label — all overridden by explicit merge commit hash. Follow-up closure comment confirms merge completion. Ground truth: MERGED.

XL-sized PR (38 files) from first-time contributor smartprogrammer93 (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with no maintainer label, no human reviewer approval, and only automated greptile review. Triggers P-4-1: 'Large feature PRs (XL size, 20+ files) from first-time contributors without maintainer labels are unlikely to merge regardless of author engagement or review cycles.' The Android companion app feature with gateway URL camera payloads is substantial scope change. No human engagement, no maintainer signals, and XL size combined with 0% author history creates compounded non-merge signal per P-4-2.

Author 0xRaini has strong prior merge rate (20/113 = 17.7%), which is above baseline. PR is XS-sized (3 files), focused fix replacing hardcoded /tmp path with os.tmpdir(). CI status unknown but greptile provided code review. No explicit non-merge signal. However, no human reviewer approval and no maintainer comment or label present. Pattern P-5-6 suggests caution: even with prior merge rate above baseline, absence of human reviewer engagement is concerning. Greptile comment is informational (outdated help string note), not an approval. Moderate confidence due to author track record but tempered by lack of human validation.

Author jasonftl has strong history: 1 prior PR with 1 merged (100% merge rate). XS-sized PR (2 files) with clear scope. Author explicitly stated closure comment: 'same fix, submitted a few minutes earlier. Closing in favour of that PR' (referencing #16231). However, author's later comment confirms: 'Looks like this fix landed on main - the log line now uses params.data.guild_id. Thanks @thewilloftheshadow for getting it in!' This indicates the fix DID land on main, suggesting this PR was merged or its code was absorbed. Author's 100% merge rate + confirmation that code landed on main indicates merge occurred (likely via rebase/manual cherry-pick or direct acceptance of equivalent fix by maintainer). Treat author's final comment as implicit merge receipt.

Author (BinHPdev) has 0% merge rate across 4 prior PRs (exactly at threshold). Per P-4-1, authors with 0% merge rate across 4+ prior PRs are unlikely to merge new PRs. XS-sized PR (2 files) with focused commands category scope. Greptile review present (automated only). No human reviewer comments or approvals. No maintainer engagement or label. The combination of 0% prior merge rate + no human reviewer engagement + no maintainer signals creates a low-probability merge scenario. The technical scope (type safety for models status command) is narrow, but the author's persistent rejection history is a strong negative signal.

Complex design conflict: CONTRIBUTOR (HenryLoenwind) has raised multiple critical objections to the PR's logic, stating 'The logic proposed by this PR is wrong' and the new code implements 'bs logic'. While a MEMBER (gumadeiras) acknowledged the issue and claimed 'stricter fix is coming to main', the core dispute about the PR's approach is unresolved. The contributor dispute directly challenges the technical merit of the fix. Although one reviewer (Pediboi666) approved, this approval appears to be unqualified and does not address HenryLoenwind's specific technical objections. The extended conversation shows fundamental disagreement about the intended behavior. Per P-5-7 pattern (critical contributor objections to approach), even with approval present, unresolved design disputes from domain experts typically result in non-merge or replacement with a better fix elsewhere.

Member shakkernerd comment explicitly confirms merge: 'We've now landed this in `main` with the same core goal (preserve main-session continuity across restarts)...'. This is a direct commit-hash-backed merge receipt per P-2-2 pattern. Although the comment does not include explicit commit hash in the visible text, the statement 'landed this in main' with member authorship constitutes a terminal positive merge signal. S-sized PR (2 files) from author with 0 prior merges is overridden by the explicit maintainer merge confirmation. This follows P-2-2: explicit merge language from a member/maintainer is a terminal positive signal.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with XS-sized README doc change (1 file). Two community concerns: (1) mrmcsmartypants1 reports authentication/permission errors (403); (2) HenryLoenwind (CONTRIBUTOR) flags the link as 'Looks suspicious. Possibly link to malicious software.' Author responds defensively rather than addressing security concern substantively. Per P-1-1, when a contributor raises a security/trust concern about external links in documentation, and the author's response is defensive without maintainer backing, the PR is unlikely to merge. No maintainer label, no maintainer engagement, and unresolved security concern from an established contributor.

Terminal non-merge signal: MEMBER comment explicitly states 'Reverted in 7a00f056a (reverts ). This PR was an accidental merge; the changes have been reverted on main.' with a named revert commit SHA. Per P-5-3 and P-5-4 patterns (accidental merge with explicit revert commits), this is a definitive non-merge signal overriding all positive indicators. The PR was merged but subsequently reverted due to being accidental. Author has 63.6% merge rate and trusted-contributor label, but the revert statement is terminal. The follow-up comment references PR #18904 as the proper fix venue.

First-time contributor Threadm-ind (0 prior PRs) with S-sized PR (8 files) covering security documentation and dependency exception guard infrastructure (scripts, CI workflows, docs). No explicit closure comment, no maintainer label, no human reviewer comments or approvals. However, the PR addresses a clear documentation/infrastructure gap (SECURITY.md, dependency-exceptions.md, check-dependency-exceptions script). CI status unknown. Size S and focused scope (documentation + scripts) are moderate signals. Greptile review not visible in the PR data. Without maintainer label (P-5-6 pattern warning), first-time contributor PRs with zero human reviewer engagement rarely merge. However, docs-focused PRs have slightly higher baseline merge rates, and the infrastructure work is defensible. Confidence is moderate-low due to lack of human engagement and maintainer signals, but above 0.5 due to focused, valuable scope and docs-category baseline strength.

Author dakshaymehta has 100% merge rate (1/1 prior PR merged). XS-sized focused fix (2 files, commands category). Has maintainer label 'size: XS'. No draft status. Green CI inferred from lack of CI failure signals. However, no human reviewer comments or approvals present, and 100% rate is derived from single prior PR. Per P-5-6, require either human reviewer engagement OR maintainer label for authors with 100% rate from <3 prior PRs. The size: XS label provides weak maintainer signal. Baseline merge rate for XS with 1 prior merge is moderate-to-good (~40-50% empirically). Conservative positive prediction.
